claim: In Germany, France, and Switzerland, you pay with euros.

supporting.text: Germany, France, and Switzerland are all members of the European Union or closely associated with it, where the euro is the official currency.

attacks.text: Germany, France, and Switzerland are all members of the European Union or closely associated with it, where the euro is the official currency.
Switzerland is not a member of the European Union and uses the Swiss franc, not the euro, as its official currency.
While Switzerland is not in the EU, it is part of the Schengen Area and many businesses near border regions accept euros for convenience.

supporting.text: Germany and France adopted the euro as their official currency in 2002 as part of the Eurozone.

attacks.text: Germany and France adopted the euro as their official currency in 2002 as part of the Eurozone.
Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc (CHF) as its official currency.
While Switzerland is not in the Eurozone, some border regions and businesses accept euros for convenience, though change is given in francs.

supporting.text: Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency, not the euro.

attacks.text: Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency, not the euro.
While Switzerland is not in the Eurozone, many businesses near the border accept euros for convenience, though change is given in Swiss francs.
Acceptance of euros in Swiss businesses is limited to tourist-heavy areas and does not reflect official currency usage, which remains the Swiss franc.
Some international transactions in Switzerland may be conducted in euros due to its status as a global financial hub.
Such transactions are typically converted to Swiss francs for settlement, as the franc is the legal tender for domestic transactions.

supporting.text: While Switzerland does not use the euro as its official currency, many businesses in border regions or tourist areas accept euros for convenience.

attacks.text: While Switzerland does not use the euro as its official currency, many businesses in border regions or tourist areas accept euros for convenience.
Accepting euros does not mean prices are set in euros; businesses often apply unfavorable exchange rates, making it costly for customers.
Many businesses display prices in both Swiss francs and euros to ensure transparency and avoid customer dissatisfaction.
Outside border regions and tourist areas, euro acceptance is rare, limiting the practical use of euros in Switzerland.
Even in non-tourist areas, some international chains and large retailers accept euros due to high foreign customer traffic.

supporting.text: The euro is the sole legal tender in Germany and France, meaning all transactions must be conducted in euros unless otherwise agreed.

attacks.text: The euro is the sole legal tender in Germany and France, meaning all transactions must be conducted in euros unless otherwise agreed.
Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc (CHF) as its legal tender, not the euro.
While Switzerland primarily uses the Swiss franc, some border regions and tourist areas may accept euros, though change is often given in francs.
In Germany and France, certain businesses in border areas or tourist zones may accept other currencies like USD or CHF, though euros remain the default.

supporting.text: The Swiss National Bank does not issue euros, and the Swiss franc is the only legal tender in Switzerland.

attacks.text: The Swiss National Bank does not issue euros, and the Swiss franc is the only legal tender in Switzerland.
While the Swiss franc is the official currency, many businesses in Switzerland accept euros, especially in tourist areas.
Acceptance of euros in Switzerland is not universal and often comes with unfavorable exchange rates or additional fees.
The claim is about legal tender, not about what businesses may optionally accept.
